text: The air froze. The chanting stopped, and several gazes converged from within the shadows—cold, silent, yet burning with a twisted fanaticism.
I didn’t hesitate. My boots slammed against the snow, shards of ice scattering as firelight flashed across my blade. The robed figures clearly hadn’t expected me to charge straight in.
The ritual’s glow still flickered. One of the sorcerers nearest to me raised his hand, chanting rapidly; the air twisted like tangled threads.
I tried to dodge but slipped on the loose stones—my swing missed. A burst of blue light exploded before my eyes.
A searing pain ripped through my arm, as if branded by hot iron. I staggered back, choking down a groan as blood dripped from my sleeve onto the ground.
“Hey! You’re bleeding!”
Lucia cried out, quickly raising her staff as a shimmering wall of light formed between us.
The blue blast slammed into it, scattering sparks. Her face was flushed from the effort, jaw clenched as she braced against the backlash.
“Forget me—save her!”
“The blood of mortals... is enough to awaken the core.”
A chill ran down my spine as I realized—the glowing sigils were spreading from where my blood had fallen, tracing back toward the pillars like veins of light devouring life.
“No—you won’t!”
Her voice was nearly drowned out by the roar around us. She lifted her staff, symbols flaring bright as daylight.
Lucia charged forward; a sphere of light burst from her staff, blasting a nearby cultist off his feet.
I forced myself up, slashing through the last binding rune around Alicia. In that instant, the ritual’s energy recoiled violently.
A shockwave hit me square in the chest, flinging me against the wall. My vision spun, ears ringing until all sound vanished into a dull hum.
Through the haze, I saw Lucia kneeling on the ground, panting. Alicia’s limp body fell from midair, caught just in time by her arms.
The light faded. The air stank of burnt blood and ozone.
“Interferers... you’ve sealed your fate.”
The cult leader’s voice was icy and sharp before his figure vanished into a ripple of warped light.
The remaining cultists scattered as the collapsing array swallowed them whole.
“Are you alright?!”
Alicia could barely stand, leaning on Lucia as they made their way toward me step by step.
“Don’t move.”
Her weak voice reached me as she drew glowing symbols in the air. A faint warmth spread through my wound, dulling the pain though the bleeding hadn’t stopped.
“It’s a temporary seal,” she said, breath unsteady. “You’ll need real rest.”
I managed a strained smile. “Guess you and Lucia saved me again.”
“Your blood... part of it was absorbed into the array. You may have been pulled into its residual circuit.”
“What does that mean?”
“For now, nothing. But if you get near another ritual like this... it might react.”
Her hand rested on mine, cold against my skin. “Promise me—don’t push yourself like that again.”
I froze. Her fingers tightened ever so slightly—gentle, but impossible to ignore.
We slowly emerged from the tunnel. The night wind cut like a blade, and the distant inn lights shimmered faintly through the snow.
“Will they come back?”
“They will.”
Alicia’s voice was soft and weary. “But we’ll be faster.”
Snow crunched beneath our boots. The wind tangled her hair, carrying away the last traces of the ritual’s scent.
I looked down at my bandaged arm, an uneasy chill creeping through me. Deep beneath the skin, the faint blue glow still pulsed like a heartbeat.
